comments_since_last_sample.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

New kitten loves being snuggled, picked up, etc.  Had her only two days before I had to trim her nails.  Yep, she hates it.  But my 7-year-old hates it, too, and I always manage to escape unscathed.  At least I can see her claws; the baby just turned four months and her claws are so tiny, but snag on everything!  She will be trimmed regularly, like it or not.  Back in the day, my purebred Siamese/Tonkinese were declawed.  Vets don’t do that anymore, and my leather furniture is now being scratched up.  Too early to think about replacements, or new drapes.

My cat loves to be handled. Belly rubs, touching her paws, teeth, ears. Being picked up. Doesn't like the vet office but while stand still and let them do whatever they gotta do. She is the sweetest cat ever. Never had a cat that liked any of that.
They should also only put their mouths and teeth on toys, not hands, for play.

Oh hey, been a while since I saw an actual LPT on here.

100% do this with your pets.

When my parents got an English setter puppy, I was enamored with her large floppy lips. I would gently stroke and stretch them and waggle them around all the time. It was just so much fun! Now, six years later, I can still play around with her lips and brush her teeth with zero hesitation on her part. That wasn’t my initial intention, but it’s a win win situation now!
And do not only put them in the carrier/the car when going to the vet...especially cats.

This is actually really good advice on here for once. We did this with our German Shepherd/Rottweiler mix from the day we got him and now he’s super chill with our toddler doing anything and everything to his face.

yeah you're gonna wanna coddle that widdle baby but that's a big no-no. you're gonna wanna let that little kitten get rubbed all over by kids, get drooled on by a st bernard, maybe lovingly gnawed on by a combination of toddler and chihuaha. take them to parties. to bars. put them on all the surfaces.

proper young animal raising is a rush to complete every type of exposure therapy in one year.
And get the adjusted to water early on for dogs! My late yorkie HATED baths & it was so hard to wash her without that poor baby having a whole anxiety attack & scratching up my arms

I can't stress this one enough, I got myself a little kitten and didn't bother messing with any of its maintenance areas, and now as a full-grown cat, I can't touch its teeth, paws, or rear end without it getting upset at me.

Also, fuck with your dog while it eats.  Pull its bowl away for a second, put your hand in between, stick your fingers in its mouth.  Seriously.  Dogs can develop feeding-time aggression, if you've ever met a dog that becomes a terrifying psycho when the bowl comes out, you know what I mean.  Interrupting your dog teaches it the food will still be there, you're not trying to eat it too, etc.
Wait is this why my cats are super chill and let me give them manipedis? Because we've been obsessed with their beans since they were babies?

A veterinarian told me this years ago when I got a new kitten, and it made it really easy for me to keep its claws trimmed, as well as every cat and dog I've had since then.

I play with their pads, gently massaging, and make a game of it, and they love it. They will voluntarily stretch their pads out of make it easier to get between their toes.
I typically do things toddlers would do but teach them to react with gentle behavior.
